name: Ourproject.org
foritself: Yes - it falls squarely in the spirit of other FOSS projects that emphasize community, sharing ideas, cooperation through copyleft licenses.
brand: Minimal branding or consideration for design on the site. Functionality is more central. No advertising is allowed on the site.
fse_mission_statement: "Free Software and Free Knowledge for a Free Society" - this mission statement is short but there is a more detailed and extended "Manifesto" for ourproject.org. This manifesto can be found at : https://ourproject.org/docman/view.php/1/19/file19.html
op_typical_member:
Software developers, artists, environmentalists and labor and human rights activists, sustainable design advocates. It has presence especially in Spain, Latin America and China, according to Alexa.com http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/ourproject.org

According to Wikipedia: OurProject projects have mainly been carried out by social movements, university-supported groups,[5][10] some free software related projects,[11] cooperatives,[12] artist collectives,[13] activist groups,[14] informal groups[15] and non-profits.[16]
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ourproject.org

Currently:
Hosted Projects: 1,104
Registered Users: 3,623
http://ourproject.org/
history:
Vicente J. Ruiz Jurado wrote the project's manifesto v. 0.1 on 6th June, 2002. Th second version, with contributions of Alberto Aldave, Jose Pablo Ferrándiz and Lola, was written 20th June, 2002.
Others have rewritten prior versions until one solidified in its current state, version 4.0 written in August 2003 by David Arroyo, Vicente J. Ruiz Jurado and Vladimir di Fiore.
http://ourproject.org/docman/view.php/1/19/file19.html

According to Wikipedia, today relevant projects that are using Ourproject infrastructure include:

the Critical Mass movement pages reference for the Hispanic movement[22][23][23][24]
The Spanish cooperative for Organic farming "Bajo el Asfalto está la Huerta", reference in the Food sovereignty movement[25][26][27][28]
the Kune project, a federated collaborative social network[29][30]
the main Free Software association of Argentina[31][32]
The community website of the Ubuntu Spanish community [33]
the internal work group of the P2P Foundation.[34]

During 2011, it has attracted interest by the new wave of protesting social movements in several areas:

It has hosted several projects related to the Arab Spring movements from Lebanon,[35] Palestine[36][37] and Syria.[38][39]
The social movement of 2011 Spanish protests repeatedly used its services.[40][41][42][43][44]
The American Occupy movement is recommending its use in its howto [45] and it recently began being used.[46][47]
resource:
Ourproject.org hosts collaborative work for Free Projects of any theme (not only free software) together with social projects, with the objective of sharing all types of knowledge under free/libre licenses. A requirement is that projects make the license clearly visible attaching it to every piece of your work.  

Hosting services include:
Mailing list
Surveys
Forums
Task management
SCM (CVS, SVN)
News service
Documentation management
FTP
Registring
File publication system
Stats
Wiki
Web hosting & subdomain
MySQL database
Full backups
E-mail Alias 
http://ourproject.org/moin/Ourproject_FAQ#Free_Projects
availability:
All projects must make use of the licenses listed below. All of the members of the community agree to allow anybody to run, copy, distribute, study and modify their programs; in other words, everybody is allowed to improve the original software.

Creative-Commons, Attribution-ShareAlike
Free Art License
GNU Free Documentation License
GNU General Public License (GPL)
Libre Designs General Public License (LDGPL)
Open Publication License, Version 1.0
The Design Science License
Artistic License
BSD License

Creative-Commons, Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike
GNU Lesser General Public License
Mozilla Public License 1.1
Public Domain

No license: only for Initiatives encouraging Free Knowledge (without contents): This option is for organizations which share our goals, but who do not need to use our services to publish any work. For instance, Solar, a Free Software organization from Argentina, use this pseudo-license. They mainly use our mailing lists, and other tools. 
http://ourproject.org/moin/Ourproject_FAQ#Free_Projects
participation:
"The idea behind the ourproject.org initiative is for it to be a tool which encourages the cooperative work effort of all types of people from every part of the world, promoting the coming together of people and the exchange of ideas and solutions to problems, with the condition that the results of the projects will remain freely accessible to whoever may find them useful, within this tool...
The ourproject.org initiative tries to translate this philosophy to other fields and subjects of life."
http://ourproject.org/docman/view.php/1/19/file19.html

The goals are stated and as a member you can have access to a list of all people involved in goal setting. Participation is open to anyone who is interested. The agenda activist and anti corporate.
tasks:
A primary task is to initiate a project by uploading documents. Other users can jump in and participate after asking the project's administrator. Participants can also take part in wikis and mailing lists devoted to projects.

tasks fall under a few different roles - some of these are vague:

Role Name: Short description of the field in which he/she collaborates.

Project Admin: the project administrators have all the rights over a project, even adding/removing other collaborators.

Task Manager: The different rights for managing this ourproject tool.

Forum: The different rights for managing this ourproject tool (none by default). Moderators can remove messages from the forum

Document Manager: The different rights for managing this ourproject tool (none by default). Editors can update/edit/delete documents of the project. 

For software projects there are these roles as well:
Registry Admin
Release Technician
CVS Commit

http://ourproject.org/moin/Ourproject_FAQ#Free_Projects
modularity: The modularity surely depends on the project. There doesn't seem to be pressure to do more or less than a person wants to. Projects vary greatly, some have concrete goals and would as a result have concrete tasks that would require investment and also commitment. Some projects do not have the same kind of tangible or concrete goals and are more akin to forums an other cultural online communities.
granularity: Again, this would depend on the project.
metrics: Many of these are ongoing projects, many have fallen by the wayside. A completed task would be a fully executed contribution on any level of granularity. Projects, as open source, aren't so much completed as brought to maturity, where they can always evolve and be refined. Additionally, many of the goals of individual projects are activist in nature and tend to focus on transition and change rather than a completion point.
alliances:
ourproject.org is an initiative of Comunes Collective a non-profit collective dedicated to facilitating the use of free/libre web tools and resources to collectives and activists alike, with the hopes of encouraging the Commons.
http://comunes.org/en/

Also:

After 9 years of existence, Ourproject has developed partnership with several organizations:

GRASIA (Group of Software Agents, Engineering & Applications)[49]: Research group of Universidad Complutense de Madrid, it is offering joint grants to students and providing hardware resources.[50]

American University of Science and Technology (Beirut): offering students the chance of collaborating with Ourproject receiving trainings in administration, or framing their senior project and Master theses in this environment.

IEPALA Foundation[51] : It has joined Ourproject, together with other free software initiatives, to build a common Data Center.[52]

Xsto.info: Free software cooperative[53] that has been providing technical infrastructure to Ourproject without charge, and recently joined the mentioned collective Data Center.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ourproject.org
clients: Clients include participants or anyone wanting to repurpose project ideas or code, provided they use free licenses.
sponsors:
The site only gets a handful of small, individual donations - the most being $300. 
http://ourproject.org/op/donate.php
summary:
Headquartered in Madrid, ourproject.org sees Free Software as an ethic or philosophy that emphasizes sharing and cooperation over personal gain, and it seeks to export this ethic to applications beyond software, to environmental or labor concerns and human rights. "The motivational factor in life is not work or money, but the passion and the desire for something to be, from a social point of view, beneficial"
http://ourproject.org/docman/view.php/1/19/file19.html

From Wikipedia:
"OurProject.org (OP) is a web-based collaborative free content repository. It acts as a central location for the construction and maintenance of social/cultural/artistic projects, providing web space and tools, and focusing in free knowledge[1] [2] . It claims to extend the ideas and methodology of free software[3] to social areas and free culture in general.[4][5] Since September 2009, Ourproject is under the Comunes Association umbrella.[6]"

Additional readings: 
Roxana, Elizabeth. "Creative Commons: A Convergence Model Between the Ideal of Commons and the Possibility of Creation in Contemporary Times, Opposed to Copyright Infringements," Social Shaping of Digital Publishing, A.A. Baptista (Eds.) IOS Press, 2012.
